[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [State Synchronization] Can asynchronous updates to different state variables create windows where the contract is in an inconsistent state? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [Migration Vulnerability] Can contract upgrades fail to properly migrate all four state variables, causing data loss or corruption? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [Access Pattern Mismatch] Can different state variables have inconsistent access control, allowing unauthorized reads or writes? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [Storage Exhaustion] Can unlimited growth of Configurations and TransactionFees mappings exhaust contract storage limits? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [Concurrent Modification] Can concurrent transactions modify ConfigurationController while Configurations are being set, causing race conditions? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [Orphaned References] Can changing ConfigurationController or MethodFeeController orphan existing TransactionFees or Configurations entries? (Medium)
[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [Backup/Recovery] Can state corruption in any of the four variables prevent recovery or backup operations? (Medium)
[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [Gas Limit Exploitation] Can reading all state variables in a single transaction exceed gas limits, causing DoS? (Low)
[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [Type Safety] Can the lack of compile-time type checking on state mappings allow runtime type errors? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: ConfigurationController + Configurations] [Authorization Bypass] Can Configurations be modified directly without checking ConfigurationController authorization? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: MethodFeeController + TransactionFees] [Fee Manipulation] Can TransactionFees be updated without verifying MethodFeeController ownership? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: ConfigurationController] [Controller Hijacking] Can the ConfigurationController be replaced by a malicious organization mid-flight during configuration updates? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: MethodFeeController] [Authority Validation] Can the MethodFeeController point to a contract that doesn't implement proper authorization checks? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All Controllers] [Default Value Attack] Can both controllers fall back to unsafe default values if not properly initialized? (Critical)
[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: Configurations] [Data Tampering] Can BytesValue in Configurations be modified in-place without proper audit logging? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: TransactionFees] [Fee Integrity] Can MethodFees in TransactionFees be corrupted to charge wrong amounts or wrong tokens? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: Configurations] [Hash Collision] Can malicious configuration keys be crafted to collide with critical system configurations? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [Checksum Missing] Can any of the state variables be modified without checksum validation, allowing undetected corruption? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: TransactionFees] [Economic Imbalance] Can TransactionFees be set to extract excessive rent from users, creating economic centralization? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: TransactionFees] [Zero Fee Exploit] Can critical methods have zero fees in TransactionFees, enabling spam and resource exhaustion? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: TransactionFees] [Fee Token Mismatch] Can TransactionFees reference non-existent or unbacked tokens, causing collection failures? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: TransactionFees] [Dynamic Fee Attack] Can an attacker manipulate TransactionFees dynamically based on transaction ordering to extract MEV? (Medium)
[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: Configurations] [Storage DoS] Can an attacker flood Configurations with garbage entries to exhaust storage? (Medium)
[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: TransactionFees] [Lookup DoS] Can excessive TransactionFees entries slow down fee lookups to unacceptable levels? (Medium)
[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Configuration/ConfigurationState.cs] [State: All] [Upgrade DoS] Can state size growth prevent contract upgrades due to migration costs? (Medium)
